contentrichtext.text: {{Use British English|date=May 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox UK place |country = England |official_name = Yardley Hastings |latitude = 52.204 |longitude = -0.734 |civil_parish = Yardley Hastings |population = 819 |population_ref = (2010 estimate)<ref name = "SNCYearBook">{{Cite book | author=SNC| coauthors= | title=South Northamptonshire Council Year Book 2010–2011| date=2010 | location=Towcester NN12 7FA | isbn= | pages=39}}</ref> |static_image= [[File:Yardley Hastings - welcome.jpg|240px]] |static_image_caption= <small> Sign to signify entrance to Yardley Hastings</small> |london_distance_mi = 64 |shire_district = [[South Northamptonshire]] |shire_county = [[Northamptonshire]] |region = East Midlands |constituency_westminster = Current: [[Northampton South (UK Parliament constituency)|Northampton South]]<br />From next General Election: [[South Northamptonshire (UK Parliament constituency)|South Northamptonshire]] |post_town = NORTHAMPTON |postcode_district = NN7 1 |postcode_area = NN |dial_code = 01604 69 |os_grid_reference = SP865570 }} '''Yardley Hastings''' is a village in the English county of [[Northamptonshire]]. It is located south-east of the county town of [[Northampton]] and is skirted on its south side by the main [[A428 road|A428]] road to [[Bedford]]. ==History== The affix 'Hastings' is the surname of the [[Earl of Pembroke|Earls of Pembroke]] of the third creation; it distinguishes the village from nearby [[Yardley Gobion]]. [[Thomas Dudley]] was born in Yardley Hastings in 1576. He sailed to New England on the [[Arbella]] in 1630 and became Governor of the Massachusetts Bay colony. He signed the charter of Harvard College in 1650. Yardley Hastings is the village in which [[Marianne Faithfull]]'s character Maggie lives in the 2007 film ''[[Irina Palm]]''. ==Buildings== The parish church is dedicated to [[St Andrew]], has a 13th century west tower and the remains of a [[Norman dynasty|Norman]] wall.<ref name = "Pevsner">{{Cite book | author=Pevsner, Nikolaus| coauthors= | title=The Buildings of England – Northamptonshire| date=1961 | publisher=Yale University Press | location=London and New Haven | isbn=978-0-300-09632-3 | pages=306–7}}</ref> It also has exceptional examples of [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] detailing.<ref>[http://www.crsbi.ac.uk/ed/nh/yardh/ Well-illustrated information about the parish church of St Andrew]</ref> The former [[Congregational]] chapel dates from 1813<ref name = "Pevsner"/> and is now home to a congregation of the [[United Reformed Church]], and together with the manse and ancillary buildings was converted into the National Youth Resource Centre of the United Reformed Church in 1991. The buildings ceased to be used for this purpose in 2003, and are now the "Crossways Retreat and Conference Centre"<ref>[http://www.crosswayscentre.org.uk Crossways Retreat and Conference Centre and Yardley Hastings United Reformed Church]</ref> initiated under the auspices of the East Midlands [[Synod]] of the United Reformed Church. The [[Manor House]] just north of the parish church has the remains of the hall of Hastings Mansion of ca. 1320–1340<ref name = "Pevsner"/>. The old [[Rectory]] in the north of the village is dated 1701<ref name = "Pevsner"/>. ==Facilities== The village has a primary school, youth club, garage, shop, post office, fish and chip shop and Indian takeaway. ==Governance== The local parish council is Yardley Hastings Parish Council. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Yardley Hastings}} *[http://www.roll-of-honour.com/Northamptonshire/YardleyHastings.html War Memorial details] {{Northamptonshire-geo-stub}} [[Category:Villages in Northamptonshire]]
